results.title: Prisoner fanzine
results.brief_description: Prisoner packed a punch when it premiered in 1979. Set in the fictional suburb of Wentworth, the female-centred prison drama reverberated around the world, spawning international adaptations and a massive cult following.
results.description: Black and White A4 fanzine published in 1996 Issue 7 January for television series Prisoner
description_for_label: Black and White A4 fanzine published in 1996 Issue 7 January for television series Prisoner

results.title: Crash zone. Vol. 4. Season 2. Eps 01-05
results.creator_credit: Bernadette O'Mahony, Steve Steve Jodrell, Julie McSwiney, Ray Boseley, David Swann, Disney Channel Australia and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crash zone”.
Episode 1: The second season of the series opens with Catalyst on the brink of financial ruin. The kids find an electronic solution to the company’s woes. Episode 2. An inventor brings radical 3-D classes to Catalyst and Alex and the team must select the perfect game for showcasing them to the world. Episode 3: The lure of a program that can order all the free stuff from the Net automatically inspires Marcello’s latest brainwave. Episode 4: The kids are torn between their principles and their allegiance to Alex when they go on strike for better conditions. Episode 5: Mike becomes drawn in to a violent game on the Net after he breaks up with Pi. Things get out of hand when ‘Damon’, an evil character from the game follows Mike into the real world. Cast includes Paul Pantano, Cassandra Magrath, Nikolai Nikolaeff, Frances Wang, Damien Bodie, Nicki Wendt and Matthew Parkinson. Teaching resources can be found at: http://www.actf.com.au/learning_centre_new/Learning_frameset.htm Accompanying website at: www.crashzone.tv
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bernadette O’Mahony, Steve Steve Jodrell, Julie McSwiney, Ray Boseley, David Swann, Disney Channel Australia and Australian Children’s Television Foundation

results.title: ‘How to throw a boomerang’ leaflet
results.brief_description: Yorta Yorta activist, artist and entrepreneur Bill Onus shared his culture as an act of resistance and reclamation of power. Through his factory and shop, Aboriginal Enterprises, he shared his art and culture, selling boomerangs and other pieces.

results.title: The Family Law Production stills
results.brief_description: Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a unique perspective on what it means to be Australian today.
